headline.main: THE JEALOUS MARCHIONESS.; TRANSLATED FROM THE FRENCH OF COUNTESS D'ASH. CHAPTER I. A MARCHIONESS' CORONET. CHAPTER II. THE SUSPICION. CHAPTER III. THE MURDERER. CHAPTER IV. THE INTERROGATORY.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a resplendent and invigorating Autumn morning, in the month of October, 1831, as the clock announced the ninth hour, that a venerable old man rung for admission to an ancient hotel in the Rue de Vendome. The porter, rushing to meet him, placed his finger to his lips to enjoin silence while crossing the court-yard.

headline.main: THE CAMPAIGN IN KANSAS.; Affairs in Kansas and the Territories Proposed Expeditions Southward Gen. Laneand Col. Jennison Jayhawking Charges, & c. Fort Leavenworth and the other Forts. FORT LEAVENWORTH TO BE FORTIFIED. GEN. JAMES H. LANE AND COL. JENNISON. LANE TO COMMAND THE DEPARTMENT. MILITARY POSITION OF THE DEPARTMENT. BRIDGE-BURNING AND HOUSE-BURNING. SKIRMISHES AND GUERILLA FIGHTING. OFFICERS AT FORT LEAVENWORTH. GAME AND THE WEATHER. RUMORED MOVEMENTS SOUTHWARD. POLITICAL THE UNITED STATES SENATORSHIP.

docs.lead_paragraph: This State, fained of old for "bleeding," would seem in no danger of losing its sanguinary reputation. There are in it at present, as I learn from pretty reliable authority, something in or about four thousand irregular levies, with some three or four hundred regulars, in possession of the forts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The children of our old townsman, HENRY CADY, Esq., have just received several letters from their father and mother, dated Richmond, and franked by Mr. ELY--the first communication they have received in several months. headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM WASHINGTON.; Nature of the British Demands Upon Our Government. A Reported Extraordinary Cabinet Session. Probable Decision to Give Up Mason and Slidell, with Conditions. The Question of the Right of Search to be Permanently Settled. No Interference in Behalf of the Rebellion. The Proposed Line of Submarine Military Telegraph. Letter from Cyrus W. Field to Gen. McClellan. A Quiet Christmas Day at the Capital. THE DEMANDS OF GREAT BRITAIN--PROBABLE ANSWER OF OUR GOVERNMENT.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cabinet is alleged to have had a special and extraordinary session to-day, to consider the demands of Lord LYONS in behalf of the British Government in the Trent affair. These demands are said to be an apology, and the restitution of MASON and SLIDELL to British custody. It is understood that our Government is ready to disavow the act of Capt. WILKES, ...

docs.snippet: The United States transport steamship Marion, Capt. J.D. PHILLIPS, from Tybee Island Dec. 20, and Port Royal harbor Dec. 21, arrived at this port yesterday.

headline.main: FROM PORT ROYAL AND TYBEE; Arrival of the Steam Transport Marion. Landing of the seventh Connecticut Regiment on Tybee Island. Bombardment Without Effect from Fort Pulaski. Important Movements Projected at Port Royal. The Railroad Between Charleston and Savannah to be Seized. A Beaufort Tradesman Returned to his Store.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States transport steamship Marion, Capt. J.D. PHILLIPS, from Tybee Island Dec. 20, and Port Royal harbor Dec. 21, arrived at this port yesterday.
